1.text:
Thank you so much! (Applause.) Thank you!
Thank you, everybody. Everybody, please have

12.text:
a seat. Hello, Brisbane! It’s good to be
back in Australia. I love Australia -- I really

24.text:
do. The only problem with Australia is every
time I come here I’ve got to sit in conference

28.text:
rooms and talk to politicians instead of go
to the beach. (Laughter.)

35.text:
To Chancellor Story, Professor Høj, faculty
and staff, distinguished guests, ladies and

43.text:
gentlemen, and most of all, the students of
the University of Queensland -- it is great

47.text:
to be here at UQ. I know that we are joined
by students from universities across this

55.text:
city, and some high school students, as well.
And so I want to thank all of the young people

61.text: especially for welcoming me here today.

63.text:
On my last visit to this magnificent country
three years ago, I had the privilege to meet

69.text:
some of the First Australians; we’re joined
by some today. So I want to begin by acknowledging

74.text:
the Traditional Owners of this land and by
paying my respects to your elders, past and

81.text:
This university is recognized as one of the
world’s great institutions of science and

87.text:
teaching. Your research led to the vaccine
that protects women and girls around the world

92.text:
from cervical cancer. Your innovations have
transformed how we treat disease and how we

98.text:
unlock new discoveries. Your studies have
warned the world about the urgent threat of

104.text:
climate change. In fact, last year I even
tweeted one of your studies to my 31 million

111.text:
followers on Twitter. (Laughter.) Just bragging
a little bit. (Applause.) I don’t think

121.text:
that’s quite as much as Lady Gaga, but it’s
pretty good. (Laughter.) That’s still not

129.text:
I thank Prime Minister Abbott and the people
of Brisbane and Queensland for hosting us

134.text:
at the G-20 Summit. This city, this part of
Australia, is just stunning -- “beautiful

140.text:
one day, and then perfect the next.” (Laughter.)
That’s what I understand. (Applause.) We

150.text:
travel a lot around the world. My staff was
very excited for “Bris Vegas.” (Laughter.)

158.text:
When I arrived they advised I needed some
XXXX. (Laughter.) You have some? (Laughter.)

169.text:
Part of the reason I have fond memories of
Australia is I spent some time here as a boy

177.text:
when I was traveling between Hawaii and Indonesia,
where I lived for several years. And when

184.text:
I returned three years ago as President, I
had the same feelings that I remembered as

189.text:
a child -- the warmth of the people of Australia,
the sense of humor. I learned to speak a little

197.text:
“strine.” (Laughter.) I’m tempted to
“give it a burl.” That’s about as far

205.text:
But I do want to take this opportunity to
express once again the gratitude of the American

209.text:
people for the extraordinary alliance with
Australia. I tell my friends and family and

216.text:
people that I meet that there is an incredible
commonality between Australia and the United

224.text:
States. And whether that’s because so many
of us traveled here as immigrants -- some

231.text:
voluntary and some not; whether it’s because
of wide open spaces and the sense of a frontier

237.text:
culture -- there’s a bond between our two
countries.

243.text:
And Australia really is everything that you
would want in a friend and in an ally. We’re

249.text:
cut from the same cloth -- immigrants from
an old world who built a new nation. We’re

255.text:
inspired by the same ideals of equality and
opportunity -- the belief everybody deserves

261.text:
a fair go, a fair shot. And we share that
same spirit -- that confidence and optimism

269.text:
-- that the future is ours to make; that we
don’t have to carry with us all the baggage

276.text:
from the past, that we can leave this world
a better, safer, more just place for future

282.text:
generations. And that’s what brings me here
today -- the future that we can build together,

288.text: here in the Asia Pacific region.

290.text:
Now, this week, I’ve traveled more than
15,000 miles -- from America to China to Burma

297.text:
to Australia. I have no idea what time it
is right now. (Laughter.) I’m completely

305.text:
upside down. But despite that distance, we
know that our world is getting smaller. One

312.text:
of Australia’s great writers spoke of this
-- a son of Brisbane and a graduate of this

318.text:
university, David Malouf. And he said, “In
that shrinking of distance that is characteristic

325.text:
of our contemporary world, even the Pacific,
largest of oceans, has become a lake.” Even

334.text: the Pacific has become a lake.

336.text:
And you see it here on this campus, where
you welcome students from all across Asia

341.text:
and around the world, including a number of
Americans. You go on exchanges, and we’re

346.text:
proud to welcome so many of you to the United
States. You walk the streets of this city

352.text:
and you hear Chinese, Vietnamese, Bahasa Indonesia,
Korean, Hindi. And in many neighborhoods more

359.text:
than half the people you meet were born somewhere
else. This is a global city in a globalized

366.text:
And I often tell young people in America that,
even with today’s challenges, this is the

372.text:
best time in history to be alive. Never in
the history of humanity have people lived

381.text:
longer, are they more likely to be healthy,
more likely to be enjoying basic security.

388.text:
The world is actually much less violent today.
You wouldn’t know it from watching television

394.text:
And that’s true here in the Asia Pacific
as well. Countries once ravaged by war, like

400.text:
South Korea and Japan, are among the world’s
most advanced economies. From the Philippines

407.text:
to Indonesia, dictatorships have given way
to genuine democracies. In China and across

414.text:
the region, hundreds of millions of people
have been lifted from poverty in the span

419.text:
of one generation, joining a global middle
class. Empowered by technology, you -- the

427.text:
young people in particular of this region
-- are connecting and collaborating across

431.text:
borders and cultures like never before as
you seek to build a new future.

439.text:
So the opportunities today are limitless.
And I don’t watch a lot of Australian television,

447.text:
so -- as you might imagine, because I’m
really far away. (Laughter.) So I don’t

456.text:
know whether some of the same tendencies that
we see in the United States -- a focus on

463.text:
conflict and disasters and problem -- dominate
what’s fed to us visually every single day.

475.text:
But when you look at the facts, opportunities
are limitless for this generation. You’re

490.text:
But what is also true, is that alongside this
dynamism, there are genuine dangers that can

498.text:
undermine progress. And we can’t look at
those problems through rose-tinted glasses.

509.text:
North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs
-- that’s a problem. Disputes over territory,

516.text:
remote islands and rocky shoals that threaten
to spiral into confrontation.

522.text:
The failure to uphold universal human rights,
denying justice to citizens and denying countries

528.text:
their full potential. Economic inequality
and extreme poverty that are a recipe for

536.text:
instability. And energy demands in growing
cities that also hasten trends towards a changing

548.text:
climate. Indeed, the same technologies that
empower citizens like you also give oppressive

555.text: regimes new tools to stifle dissent.

558.text:
So the question that we face is, which of
these futures will define the Asia Pacific

563.text:
in the century to come? Do we move towards
further integration, more justice, more peace?

572.text:
Or do we move towards disorder and conflict?
Those are our choices -- conflict or cooperation?

586.text:
Here in Australia three years ago, in your
parliament, I made it clear where the United

589.text:
States stands. We believe that nations and
peoples have the right to live in security

595.text:
and peace; that an effective security order
for Asia must be based -- not on spheres of

601.text:
influence, or coercion, or intimidation where
big nations bully the small -- but on alliances

607.text:
of mutual security, international law and
international norms that are upheld, and the

617.text:
We believe in open markets and trade that
is fair and free -- a level playing field

622.text:
where economies play by the same rules; where
the purpose of trade is not simply to extract

628.text:
resources from the ground, but to build true
partnerships that raise capacity and living

633.text:
standards in poor countries; where small business
owners and entrepreneurs and innovators have

638.text:
the freedom to dream and create and flourish;
and how well a country does is based on how

646.text: well they empower their individual citizens.

651.text:
And we believe in democracy -- that the only
real source of legitimacy is the consent of

657.text:
the people; that every individual is born
equal with fundamental rights, inalienable

666.text:
rights, and that it is the responsibility
of governments to uphold these rights. This

671.text:
is what we stand for. That is our vision -- the
future America is working toward in the Asia

682.text:
Now as a Pacific power, the United States
has invested our blood and treasure to advance

692.text:
this vision. We don't just talk about it;
we invest in this vision. Generations of Americans

702.text:
have served and died in the Asia Pacific so
that the people of the region might live free.

711.text:
So no one should ever question our resolve
or our commitment to our allies.

717.text:
When I assumed office, leaders and people
across the region were expressing their desire

720.text:
for greater American engagement. And so as
President, I decided that -- given the importance

725.text:
of this region to American security, to American
prosperity -- the United States would rebalance

731.text:
our foreign policy and play a larger and lasting
role in this region. That’s exactly what

738.text:
Today, our alliances, including with Australia,
are stronger than they have ever been. American

747.text:
exports to this region have reached record
levels. We’ve deepened our cooperation with

752.text:
emerging powers and regional organizations,
especially in Southeast Asia. We expanded

758.text:
our partnerships with citizens as they've
worked to bolster their democracies. And we’ve

763.text:
shown that -- whether it’s a tsunami or
an earthquake or a typhoon -- when our friends

768.text:
are in need, America shows up. We’re there
to help. In good times and bad, you can count

776.text: on the United States of America.

778.text:
Now, there have been times when people have
been skeptical of this rebalancing. They're

787.text:
wondering whether America has the staying
power to sustain it. And it's true that in

792.text:
recent years pressing events around the world
demand our attention. As the world’s only

797.text:
superpower, the United States has unique responsibilities
that we gladly embrace. We’re leading the

804.text:
international community in the fight to destroy
the terrorist group ISIL. We're leading in

810.text:
dealing with Ebola in West Africa and in opposing
Russia’s aggression against Ukraine -- which

818.text:
is a threat to the world, as we saw in the
appalling shoot-down of MH17, a tragedy that

825.text:
took so many innocent lives, among them your
fellow citizens. As your ally and friend,

832.text:
America shares the grief of these Australian
families, and we share the determination of

837.text:
your nation for justice and accountability.
So, yes, we have a range of responsibilities.

847.text: That's the deal. It's a burden we gladly shoulder.

854.text:
But even in each of these international efforts,
some of our strongest partners are our allies

858.text:
and friends in this region, including Australia.
So meeting these other challenges in the world

865.text:
is not a distraction from our engagement in
this region, it reinforces our engagement

870.text:
in this region. Our rebalance is not only
about the United States doing more in Asia,

876.text:
it’s also about the Asia Pacific region
doing more with us around the world.

882.text:
So I’m here today to say that American leadership
in the Asia Pacific will always be a fundamental

890.text:
focus of my foreign policy. It won’t always
make the headlines. It won’t always be measured

900.text:
in the number of trips I make -- although
I do keep coming back. (Laughter.) But day

908.text:
in, and day out, steadily, deliberately, we
will continue to deepen our engagement using

912.text:
every element of American power -- diplomacy,
military, economic, development, the power

918.text:
of our values and our ideals. And so in the
time I have left, I want to describe, specifically,

925.text: what America intends to do in the coming years.

928.text:
First, the United States will continue strengthening
our alliances. With Japan, we’ll finalize

935.text:
new defense guidelines and keep realigning
our forces for the future. With the Republic

939.text:
of Korea, we’ll deepen our collaboration,
including on missile defense, to deter and

943.text:
defend against North Korean threats. With
the Philippines, we’ll train and exercise

949.text:
more to prepare for challenges from counterterrorism
and piracy to humanitarian crises and disaster

955.text:
relief. And here in Australia, more U.S. Marines
will rotate through to promote regional stability,

965.text:
Although I will say when I went out to Darwin
to inaugurate the new rotation of our U.S.

976.text:
Marines there, that the mayor, I think it
was, took out crocodile insurance, which disturbed

982.text:
me. (Laughter.) I mean I was flattered that
he took out insurance on my behalf. (Laughter.)

990.text:
But I did ask my ambassador what this was
all about. (Laughter.) And he described to

994.text:
me how crocodiles kill more people than sharks,
and there are just a lot of things in Australia

1000.text:
that can kill you. (Laughter.) But that's
an aside. (Laughter.)

1008.text:
We have an ironclad commitment to the sovereignty,
independence, and security of every ally.

1014.text:
And we’ll expand cooperation between allies,
because we believe we’re stronger when we

1022.text:
The United States will continue to modernize
our defense posture across the region. We’ll

1030.text:
deploy more of our most advanced military
capabilities to keep the peace and deter aggression.

1036.text:
Our presence will be more distributed, including
in Southeast Asia with partners like Singapore.

1041.text:
And we’ll increase military training and
education, including working with the military

1047.text:
partners we have in this region around the
respect for human rights by military and police.

1053.text:
And by the end of this decade, a majority
of our Navy and Air Force fleets will be based

1059.text:
out of the Pacific, because the United States
is, and will always be, a Pacific power.

1064.text:
And keep in mind we do this without any territorial
claims. We do this based on our belief that

1078.text:
a region that is peaceful and prosperous is
good for us and is good for the world.

1087.text:
The United States will continue broadening
our cooperation with emerging powers and emerging

1093.text:
economies. We intend to help Vietnam pursue
economic reforms and new maritime capabilities.

1101.text:
We will continue to move ahead with our comprehensive
partnership with Indonesia, which is a strong

1107.text:
example of diversity and pluralism. We’ll
continue to expand ties with Malaysia, a growing

1113.text:
center of entrepreneurship and innovation.
And we support a greater role in the Asia

1119.text:
Pacific for India, which is the world’s
largest democracy.

1123.text:
The United States will continue expanding
our engagement with regional institutions,

1129.text:
because together we can meet shared challenges
-- from preventing the horror of human trafficking

1135.text:
to countering violent extremism, to stemming
the flow of foreign terrorist fighters. Together,

1141.text:
we can improve maritime security, upholding
freedom of navigation and encouraging territorial

1147.text:
disputes are resolved peacefully. We’ll
work with partners to develop the East Asia

1154.text:
Summit into the region’s leading forum for
addressing political and security challenges.

1159.text:
And we’ll support ASEAN’s effort to reach
a code of conduct with China that reinforces

1164.text: international law in the South China Sea.

1170.text:
And speaking of China, the United States will
continue to pursue a constructive relationship

1175.text:
with China. By virtue of its size and its
remarkable growth, China will inevitably play

1184.text:
a critical role in the future of this region.
And the question is, what kind of role will

1188.text:
it play? I just came from Beijing, and I said
there, the United States welcomes the continuing

1197.text:
rise of a China that is peaceful and prosperous
and stable and that plays a responsible role

1202.text:
in world affairs. It is a remarkable achievement
that millions of people have been lifted out

1211.text:
of poverty in China because of the extraordinary
growth rates that they’ve experienced. That

1216.text:
is a good thing. We should want and welcome
that kind of development.

1224.text:
And if, in fact, China is playing the role
of a responsible actor that is peaceful and

1230.text:
prosperous and stable, that is good for this
region, it’s good for the world, it’s

1233.text:
good for the United States. So we’ll pursue
cooperation with China where our interests

1239.text:
overlap or align. And there are significant
areas of overlap: More trade and investment;

1246.text:
more communications between our militaries
to prevent misunderstandings or possible conflict;

1252.text:
more travel and exchanges between our people;
and more cooperation on global challenges,

1262.text:
But in this engagement we are also encouraging
China to adhere to the same rules as other

1267.text:
nations -- whether in trade or on the seas.
And in this engagement we will continue to

1276.text:
be frank about where there are differences,
because America will continue to stand up

1280.text:
for our interests and principles, including
our unwavering support for the fundamental

1292.text:
We do not benefit from a relationship with
China or any other country in which we put

1298.text:
our values and our ideals aside. And for the
young people, practicality is a good thing.

1307.text:
There are times where compromise is necessary.
That’s part of wisdom. But it’s also important

1319.text:
to hang on to what you believe -- to know
what you believe and then be willing to stand

1323.text:
up for it. And what’s true for individuals
is also true for countries.

1328.text:
The United States will continue to promote
economic growth that is sustainable and shared.

1334.text:
So we’re going to work with APEC to tear
down barriers to trade and investment and

1338.text:
combat the corruption that steals from so
many citizens. We’ll keep opposing special

1343.text:
preferences for state-owned companies. We’ll
oppose cyber-theft of trade secrets. We’ll

1349.text:
work with partners to invest in the region’s
infrastructure in a way that’s open and

1353.text:
transparent. We’ll support reforms that
help economies transition to models that boost

1358.text:
domestic demand and invest in people and their
education and their skills.

1363.text:
We’ll keep leading the effort to realize
the Trans-Pacific Partnership to lower barriers,

1368.text:
open markets, export goods, and create good
jobs for our people. But with the 12 countries

1376.text:
of the TPP making up nearly 40 percent of
the global economy, this is also about something

1380.text:
bigger. It is our chance to put in place new,
high standards for trade in the 21st century

1385.text:
that uphold our values. So, for example, we
are pushing new standards in this trade agreement,

1392.text:
requiring countries that participate to protect
their workers better and to protect the environment

1397.text:
better, and protect intellectual property
that unleashes innovation, and baseline standards

1405.text: to ensure transparency and rule of law.

1409.text:
It’s about a future where instead of being
dependent on a single market, countries integrate

1414.text:
their economies so they’re innovating and
growing together. That’s what TPP does.

1419.text:
That’s why it would be a historic achievement.
That’s why I believe so strongly that we

1423.text:
need to get it done -- not just for our countries,
but for the world.

1426.text:
But that’s also why it’s hard -- because
we’re asking all these countries at various

1432.text:
stages of development to up their game. And
it requires big transitions for a lot of these

1438.text:
countries, including for the United States.
And TPP is just one part of our overall focus

1445.text:
on growing the global economy. That’s what
the G-20 meetings are all about.

1449.text:
Over the last few years, the United States
has put more people back to work than all

1454.text:
other advanced economies combined. But America
can’t be expected to just carry the world

1462.text:
economy on our back. So here in Brisbane,
the G-20 has a responsibility to act -- to

1469.text:
boost demand, and invest more in infrastructure,
and create good jobs for the people of all

1479.text:
As we develop, as we focus on our econ, we
cannot forget the need to lead on the global

1486.text:
fight against climate change. Now, I know
that’s -- (applause) -- I know there’s

1498.text:
been a healthy debate in this country about
it. (Laughter.) Here in the Asia Pacific,

1508.text:
nobody has more at stake when it comes to
thinking about and then acting on climate

1518.text:
Here, a climate that increases in temperature
will mean more extreme and frequent storms,

1525.text:
more flooding, rising seas that submerge Pacific
islands. Here in Australia, it means longer

1533.text:
droughts, more wildfires. The incredible natural
glory of the Great Barrier Reef is threated.

1545.text:
Worldwide, this past summer was the hottest
on record. No nation is immune, and every

1556.text: nation has a responsibility to do its part.

1561.text:
And you’ll recall at the beginning I said
the United States and Australia has a lot

1566.text:
in common. Well, one of the things we have
in common is we produce a lot of carbon. Part

1570.text:
of it’s this legacy of wide-open spaces
and the frontier mentality, and this incredible

1577.text:
abundance of resources. And so, historically,
we have not been the most energy-efficient

1583.text:
of nations, which means we’ve got to step
up.

1588.text:
In the United States, our carbon pollution
is near its lowest levels in almost two decades

1595.text:
-- and I’m very proud of that. Under my
Climate Action Plan, we intend to do more.

1600.text:
In Beijing, I announced our ambitious new
goal -- reducing our net greenhouse gas emissions

1605.text:
by 26 to 28 percent below 2005 levels by the
year 2025, which will double the pace at which

1613.text:
we’re reducing carbon pollution in the United
States. Now, in a historic step, China made

1623.text:
its own commitment, for the first time, agreeing
to slow, peak and then reverse the course

1629.text:
of China’s carbon emissions. And the reason
that’s so important is because if China,

1635.text:
as it develops, adapts the same per capita
carbon emissions as advanced economies like

1641.text:
the United States or Australia, this planet
doesn’t stand a chance, because they’ve

1649.text:
So them setting up a target sends a powerful
message to the world that all countries -- whether

1655.text:
you are a developed country, a developing
country, or somewhere in between -- you’ve

1660.text:
got to be able to overcome old divides, look
squarely at the science, and reach a strong

1668.text:
global climate agreement next year. And if
China and the United States can agree on this,

1674.text:
then the world can agree on this. We can get
this done. And it is necessary for us to get

1688.text:
it done. (Applause.) Because I have not had
to go to the Great Barrier Reef -- (laughter)

1699.text:
-- and I want to come back, and I want my
daughters to be able to come back, and I want

1702.text:
them to be able to bring their daughters or
sons to visit. (Applause.) And I want that

1714.text:
Now, today, I’m announcing that the United
States will take another important step. We

1717.text:
are going to contribute $3 billion to the
Green Climate Fund so we can help developing

1725.text:
nations deal with climate change. (Applause.)
So along with the other nations that have

1738.text:
pledged support, this gives us the opportunity
to help vulnerable communities with an early-warning

1743.text:
system, with stronger defenses against storm
surges, climate-resilient infrastructure.

1751.text:
It allows us to help farmers plant more durable
crops. And it allows us to help developing

1758.text:
countries break out of this false choice between
development and pollution; let them leap-frog

1767.text:
some of the dirty industries that powered
our development; go straight to a clean-energy

1775.text:
economy that allows them to grow, create jobs,
and at the same time reduce their carbon pollution.

1786.text:
So we’ve very proud of the work that we
have already done. We are mindful of the great

1793.text:
work that still has to be done on this issue.
But let me say, particularly again to the

1798.text:
young people here: Combating climate change
cannot be the work of governments alone. Citizens,

1806.text:
especially the next generation, you have to
keep raising your voices, because you deserve

1813.text:
to live your lives in a world that is cleaner
and that is healthier and that is sustainable.

1819.text:
But that is not going to happen unless you
are heard.

1825.text:
It is in the nature of things, it is in the
nature of the world that those of us who start

1831.text:
getting gray hair are a little set in our
ways, that interests are entrenched -- not

1838.text:
because people are bad people, it’s just
that’s how we’ve been doing things. And

1841.text:
we make investments, and companies start depending
on certain energy sources, and change is uncomfortable

1851.text:
and difficult. And that’s why it’s so
important for the next generation to be able

1856.text:
to step and say, no, it doesn’t have to
be this way. You have the power to imagine

1865.text:
a new future in a way that some of the older
folks don’t always have.

1873.text:
And the same is true when it comes to issues
of democracy and human rights. There are times

1883.text:
where when we speak out on these issues we
are told that democracy is just a Western

1890.text:
value. I fundamentally disagree with that.
(Applause.) Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, they

1902.text:
have built thriving democracies. Filipinos
showed us the strength of People Power. Indonesians

1909.text:
just voted in a historic election. I just
came from Burma; this is a place that for

1917.text:
40 years was under the grip of a military
junta, one of the most closed and oppressive

1933.text:
nations on Earth. And there, I was inspired
by citizens and civil society and parliamentarians

1941.text:
who are now working to sustain a transition
to a democratic future. I had a town hall

1946.text:
meeting with young people like you, in which
they were asking, what does it mean to create

1952.text:
rule of law? And how should we deal with ethnic
diversity in our city? You could feel the

1957.text:
excitement. What does a free press look like,
and how does it operate? And how do we make

1963.text:
sure that journalism is responsible? Incredible
ferment and debate that’s taking place.

1971.text:
Those young people, they want the same things
that you do. The notion that somehow they’re

1978.text:
less interested in opportunity or less interested
in avoiding arbitrary arrest, or less interested

1986.text:
in being censored is fundamentally untrue.
Today, people in Hong Kong are speaking out

1999.text:
And so here in Asia and around the world,
America supports free and fair elections,

2005.text:
because citizens must be free to choose their
own leaders -- as in Thailand where we are

2010.text:
urging a quick return to inclusive, civilian
rule. We support freedom of assembly, and

2016.text:
freedom of speech, and freedom of the press,
a free and open Internet, strong civil societies,

2024.text:
because the voices of the people must be heard
and leaders must be held accountable -- even

2028.text:
though it’s uncomfortable sometimes. I promise
you, if you lead a country, there are times

2034.text:
where you are aggravated with people voicing
opinions that seem to think you’re doing

2044.text:
something wrong. You prefer everybody just
praise you. I understand. (Laughter.) But

2052.text: that’s not how societies move forward.

2058.text:
We support strong institutions and independent
judiciaries and open government, because the

2064.text:
rule of force must give way to the rule of
law.

2071.text:
And in that same fashion, the United States
will continue to stand up for the inherent

2074.text:
dignity of every human being. Now, dignity
begins with the most basic of needs -- a life

2083.text:
free of hunger and disease and want. So, yes,
we’ll speak out on behalf of human rights,

2090.text:
but we are also going to invest in the agriculture
that allows farmers to feed their families

2094.text:
and boost their incomes. We’ll invest in
the development that promotes growth and helps

2100.text:
end the injustice of extreme poverty in places
like the Lower Mekong Delta. We intend to

2108.text:
partner with all the countries in the region
to create stronger public health systems and

2114.text:
new treatments that save lives and realize
our goals of being the first AIDS-free generation.

2121.text:
And what we’ve learned from the Ebola outbreak
is that in this globalized world, where the

2130.text:
Pacific is like a lake, if countries are so
poor that they can’t afford basic public

2139.text:
health infrastructure, that threatens our
health. We cannot built a moat around our

2148.text:
countries, and we shouldn’t try. What we
should be doing is making sure everybody has

2154.text:
some basic public health systems that allow
for early warning when outbreaks of infectious

2161.text:
disease may occur. That’s not just out of
charity. It is in our self-interest.

2168.text:
And again, I want to speak to young people
about this. When we talk about these issues

2173.text:
of development, when we invest in the wellbeing
of people on the other side of the globe,

2182.text:
when we stand up for freedom, including occasionally
having to engage in military actions, we don’t

2190.text:
do that just because we are charitable. We
do that because we recognize that we are linked,

2197.text:
and that if somebody, some child is stricken
with a curable disease on the other side of

2204.text:
the world, at same point that could have an
impact on our child.

2209.text:
We’ll advance human dignity by standing
up for the rights of minorities, because no

2217.text:
one’s equality should ever be denied. We
will stand up for freedom of religion -- the

2222.text:
right of every person to practice their faith
as they choose -- because we are all children

2227.text:
of God, and we are all fallible. And the notion
that we, as a majority, or the state should

2237.text:
tell somebody else what to believe with respect
to their faith, is against our basic values.

2248.text:
We will stand up for our gay and lesbian fellow
citizens, because they need to be treated

2254.text:
equally under the law. (Applause.) We will
stand up for the rights and futures of our

2267.text:
wives and daughters and partners, because
I believe that the best measure of whether

2277.text:
a nation is going to be successful is whether
they are tapping the talents of their women

2280.text:
and treating them as full participants in
politics and society and the econ. (Applause.)

2292.text:
And we’re going to continue to invest in
the future of this region, and that means

2300.text:
you, this region’s youth -- all of you -- your
optimism, your idealism, your hopes. I see

2308.text:
it everywhere I go. I spend a lot of time
with young people. I spend a lot of time with

2313.text:
old people, too. But I prefer spending time
with young people. (Laughter.) I meet them

2318.text:
in Tokyo and Seoul, and Manila and Jakarta.
It’s the spirit of young men and women in

2324.text:
Kuala Lumpur and Rangoon, who are participating
in our Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative.

2330.text: And like you, they’re ready to lead.

2334.text:
To the young woman with an idea who dreams
of starting her own business -- if she just

2338.text:
had the network, if she just had the capital,
America wants to be her partner, because we

2344.text:
believe in the entrepreneur that you can be,
the innovations you can spark and the jobs

2348.text:
you can create. And when you succeed, we’ll
all be more prosperous.

2352.text:
To the young man who’s working late in a
clinic, tending to a patient, who dreams not

2357.text:
just of treating diseases, but preventing
them -- if I just had the resources, if I

2361.text:
just had the support -- we want to be your
partner, because we believe in the advocate

2369.text:
that you can be, and in the families you can
reach and the lives you can save. And when

2372.text: you succeed, our world will be better.

2378.text:
To the young woman tired of the tensions in
her community, who dreams of helping her neighbors

2382.text:
see beyond differences -- if she could just
start a dialogue, if she knew how others had

2387.text:
walked the same path -- well, America wants
to be your partner, because we believe in

2392.text:
the activist that you can be, and the empathy
that you can build, and the understanding

2396.text:
you can foster between people. And when you
succeed, our world will be a little more peaceful.

2402.text:
And to the young man who believes his voice
isn’t being heard, who dreams of bringing

2407.text:
people like him together across his country
-- if he just knew how to organize and mobilize

2412.text:
them -- we want to be your partner, because
we believe in the leaders that you can be,

2416.text:
in the difference you can make to ignite positive
change. And when you succeed, the world will

2422.text:
So that’s the future we can build together.
That’s the commitment America is making

2428.text:
in the Asia Pacific. It’s a partnership
not just with nations, but with people, with

2434.text:
you, for decades to come. Bound by the values
we share, guided by the vision we seek, I

2441.text:
am absolutely confident we can advance the
security and the prosperity and the dignity

2446.text:
of people across this region. And in pursuit
of that future, you will have no greater friend

2452.text: than the United States of America.

2454.text:
So thank you very much. God bless Australia.
(Applause.) God bless America. God bless our
